thread.title_full: Hackers can exploit Siri to control your iPhone and run up massive bills - Mirror Online

author: Ben Cusack
title: Hackers can exploit Siri to control your iPhone and run up massive bills
text:
Millions of smartphone users could be at risk of massive bills after a simple security flaw means any locked handset can be used to make calls - using SIRI .
Apple's Siri can be used to bypass pin numbers and the in-built fingerprint scanner to make calls from any locked device, including to premium rate phonelines.
Microsoft's equivalent to Siri, Cortana, can also be used to bypass security measures and make calls to expensive numbers without being unlocked - and can also send texts.
The massive security flaw means people who lose their phone could be at risk of being lumped with giant bills, because whoever finds it could make lengthy calls to long-distance or premium rate numbers.
The high tech personal assistants, built into millions of current generation smartphones, can be disabled, but because their default setting is on, most people do not turn them off, even if they are never used.
They can also be used as diaries, meaning whoever is in possession of the phone can see the general daily tasks of the phone's rightful owner - and possibly even get directions to their house if the home address is saved in the phone.
Using Siri or Cortana on a locked phone can also send text messages to contacts, as well as to unsaved numbers.
A security expert, who cannot be named, said: "This is a technological oversight by the phones' manufacturers, and can be easily exploited with potentially devastating consequences.
"It would only take a second for a thief to swipe an unattended phone, and then they would be able to make as many calls, and potentially access sensitive information.
"If you can get somebody's address, you can get their life, and there's nothing that Microsoft or Apple have done to prevent that.
"The annoyance of having an extremely large bill is nothing in comparison to having your identity stolen and potentially having your entire life turned upside down."
Reuters
Apple refused to comment on the massive security error.
A spokesperson for Apple said: "Like usual, it's something to be aware of but not overly concerned about."
They claim that the Voice ID on the iPhone 6s blocks people voice-activating Siri, but there are currently no ways to avoid locked phones being used to make calls if they the button can be pressed.
